Waldheim to speak here October 26
United Nations Secretary
General Kurt Waldheim will
speak at Homewood, Thursday,
October 26 in Shriver Hall in the
1972 George Huntington
Williams Memorial Lecture.
Waldheim was elected to the
UN post in December 1971 after
serving as Austria's Permanent
representative to the world body
since October of 1970. He had
also run unsuccessfully for the
Presidency of Austria in April
1971.
Presidential
Prior to his presidential race,
he. had served as Austria's

Foreign Minister for two years,
starting in January 1968. He
began his diplomatic career in
1945, after graduating from the
University of Vienna and the
Vienna Consular Academy.
'48 to '51
From 1948 to 1951, Waldheim
served as First Secretary at the
Austrian Embassy in Paris and
was head of the personnel
department of the Foreign
Affairs Ministry from 1951 to
1955. Also in 1955, he became
Austria's permanent observer at
the UN and was head of the
Austrain Mission at the time of

his nation's admission to the
world group.
From 1956 to 1958, Waldheim
served as Minister Plenipotentiary
and then Ambassador to Canada.
He later headed two other offices
in the Austrian Foreign Ministry.
The lectureship at which
Waldheim will speak was
established in a gift to Hopkins
from George Huntington
Williams, who directed that half
the income from the donation be
used to support geographical
research and the other half for
lectures "on topics of widespread
contemporary interest."

Previous lecturers have
included Waldheim's immediate
predecessor at the UN pst, U
Thant of Burma, who served as
Secretary General from 1961 to
1 971, former United States
Secretary of State Dean Rusk,
diplomat and author George F.
Kennan, John G. Winant and the
late Czech Foreign Minister Jan
Masaryk.
Although the Williams Lecture
is an annual event, it did not take
place last year. The last lecture
was in the spring of 1971 when
Gordon McDonald of the Council
on Environmental Quality spoke.

.Even more disturbing than his 1946

Jung makes the distinction between

impressionable self. An intriguing

least of a "rational" assassination.

Lamar Hunt: tennis nemisis
The sport of professional
tennis is currently riding the crest
of a tremendous wave of
popularity throughout the world;
yet beneath this surface of
overwhelming success, seeds of
discontent and dissension have
arisen.
Three -time Wimbledon
champion John Newcombe of
Australia recently announced
that he is leaving the World
Championship Tennis troupe in
order to play independently, and
it is expected that many other
top-notch performers will follow
his example. Although such
actions pose a serious threat to
the harmony of professional
tennis in the world, Newcombe
and his followers deserve to be
commended not condemned. The
controversy which they created
has helped to shed light on the
problems of professional tennis,
and on the dangerous course the
sport seems bent on pursUing.
Guaranteed Money
Within the professional tennis
ranks, there are two types of
players: the contract, and the
independent, pros. The contract
players are those who have
offered their services to World
Championship Tennis, headed by
Texas millionaire Lamar Hunt.
Each player is guaranteed a
certain amount of money for the
year, and may keep all prize
money that he makes above and

beyond that figure. In return, he
must agree to play 20 sanctioned
WCT tournaments plus 10 others
per year, at Hunt's discretion. In
effect, he is a slave to the
organization.
The independent pros, on the
other hand, are free to accept
prize money and are their own
bosses, free to play or pass up
tournaments as they see fit. Stan
Smith, Clark Graebner, and Hie
Nastase are among the most
famous independent pros, and it
is this type of player that
Newcombe and others seek to
become.
Worthless
The principal advantage
derived from belonging to Hunt's
tour is that you are guaranteed
an annual salary: however, this is
ceasing to be an important
consideration. The better players
are finding out that they can
make just as much money
outside the group, and can select
which tournaments to enter. In
1970, for example, Rod Laver
was guaranteed winnings of
$90,000 by WCT, and wound up
collecting $201,453 in prize
money. In effect, his guarantee
was worthless. Now, more and
more of the super-stars are
finding this out, and as a result,
Hunt's empire is beginning to
crumble.
It is no surprise that this is
occurring, because the WCT is

built on a contradiction. Hunt
makes his money by delivering
the "stars", or big drawing cards,
to the various tournaments. But
his contract disenchants the more
established players, the "stars",
because they don't need his'
guarantee and resent the
obligations implicit in the
agreement.

John Ham-e;it
Lamar Hunt is running a
business, not trying to promote a
sport, and this is symptomatic of
a discouraging trend in world
tennis. When business consumes
sport it is time for reevaluation,
and such time is rapidly
approaching.

.Even more disturbing than his 1946

Lamar Hunt: tennis nemisis
The sport of professional
tennis is currently riding the crest
of a tremendous wave of
popularity throughout the world;
yet beneath this surface of
overwhelming success, seeds of
discontent and dissension have
arisen.
Three -time Wimbledon
champion John Newcombe of
Australia recently announced
that he is leaving the World
Championship Tennis troupe in
order to play independently, and
it is expected that many other
top-notch performers will follow
his example. Although such
actions pose a serious threat to
the harmony of professional
tennis in the world, Newcombe
and his followers deserve to be
commended not condemned. The
controversy which they created
has helped to shed light on the
problems of professional tennis,
and on the dangerous course the
sport seems bent on pursUing.
Guaranteed Money
Within the professional tennis
ranks, there are two types of
players: the contract, and the
independent, pros. The contract
players are those who have
offered their services to World
Championship Tennis, headed by
Texas millionaire Lamar Hunt.
Each player is guaranteed a
certain amount of money for the
year, and may keep all prize
money that he makes above and

beyond that figure. In return, he
must agree to play 20 sanctioned
WCT tournaments plus 10 others
per year, at Hunt's discretion. In
effect, he is a slave to the
organization.
The independent pros, on the
other hand, are free to accept
prize money and are their own
bosses, free to play or pass up
tournaments as they see fit. Stan
Smith, Clark Graebner, and Hie
Nastase are among the most
famous independent pros, and it
is this type of player that
Newcombe and others seek to
become.
Worthless
The principal advantage
derived from belonging to Hunt's
tour is that you are guaranteed
an annual salary: however, this is
ceasing to be an important
consideration. The better players
are finding out that they can
make just as much money
outside the group, and can select
which tournaments to enter. In
1970, for example, Rod Laver
was guaranteed winnings of
$90,000 by WCT, and wound up
collecting $201,453 in prize
money. In effect, his guarantee
was worthless. Now, more and
more of the super-stars are
finding this out, and as a result,
Hunt's empire is beginning to
crumble.
It is no surprise that this is
occurring, because the WCT is

built on a contradiction. Hunt
makes his money by delivering
the "stars", or big drawing cards,
to the various tournaments. But
his contract disenchants the more
established players, the "stars",
because they don't need his'
guarantee and resent the
obligations implicit in the
agreement.

John Ham-e;it
Lamar Hunt is running a
business, not trying to promote a
sport, and this is symptomatic of
a discouraging trend in world
tennis. When business consumes
sport it is time for reevaluation,
and such time is rapidly
approaching.
